Comments_List: This class was so helpful in understanding world events, both present and past, with a more scholarly lens.
This gives students a really good grasp on the different international relations theories and ways in which to apply that to today's current events.
I learned how to analyze current affairs and gained the tools necessary to come up with my own opinions on events in international relations.
This class teaches someone the basics of political theory.
This course provides a survey of international relations theory and applies this theory to various historical and current events.
Insight into various lenses of international relations and a newly acquired liking towards Constructivism and Domestic Politics theories.
I learned about the modes of IR analysis and some interesting examples.
Very informative, very good

Great class! Learned the foundational theories of International relations. I can read and dissect the economist and Foreign Affairs with a much greater level of understanding and engagement. WOW! Great.
I am now able to apply the international relations theoretical perspectives to both current and historic international events.
Pertinent information for real world
I developed a broad knowledge of history relating to international relations since the Incas and Thucydides. I also developed an understanding of ir theory lenses and how they apply.
I relearned some of the basic history from APUSH and AP Euro in addition to learning the framing theories of international relations.

I learned a great deal of information about political history and the development of international relations over the course of the years, as well as the theoretical base underlying how we view international relations.
An introduction to IR theory, the past 13,000 of military history, and current problems in the IR field.
Applying classroom learning to real world experiences
IR lenses, history
I learned about theoretical lenses to describe international relations. In addition, I learned about the history of statecraft and why many traditional theories are breaking down in the modern world.
I learned a great deal about current theories and events in international relations, as well as an understanding of ways to analyze events through the use of those theories.
Basic understanding of international relations theory
I learned about various international relations theories and important international events from history and today.

This was a pretty great intro course. I especially loved the focus on applying perspectives to modern events in the second half of the course. Some of the earlier material, such as history of Europe, seemed a little bit drawn out - it would have been more interesting to tell some of the story in terms of specifically how other nations addressed the IR issues instead of just presenting some of the historical details.
I found it interesting to examine events in world history through particular lenses. I think the lenses we applied are good building blocks for my future studies in international relations.

A much improved understanding of the theories which underpin international relations and the ability to apply these to different current-day issues. I felt this course both strengthened by conceptual understanding of international relations and improved my critical thinking skills regarding a subject which I am passionate about.
I learned how to theoretical analyze international relations

The course provided a broad theoretical foundation whose applications were shown in both historical and modern contexts. The class helped me think intelligently about international relations and helped me understand different facets of current policies and events that I did not know before.
I learnt how to use different theoretical lenses to evaluate international affairs. I learnt how to construct an argument using multiple perspectives.
I really enjoyed this class, though it challenged me a lot. I found IR theory to be relatively interesting but at times also a bit inapplicable and out of the scope of certain issues.

I got a broad sense of historical and current issues in International relations. I got a grasp of the scholarly theories of the international system. I learnt how to think about the nature of the international system and the different forces guiding it right now. I learnt about topics that are increasingly relevant and interesting.
I learned about the different international relations perspectives.
I learned a lot of the history behind current international relations which was extremely helpful.
I gained an understanding of the major schools of international relations thought and how to apply them to historical and current events.

Intro to IR has been one of the best classes I've taken at Yale. It has given me the tools to understand world politics in new insightful ways. With the combination of historical contexts, theoretical explanations, and contemporary events, I am able to have a more comprehensive and critical view on world politics and explain why things are the way they are. I hope to use these tools and insights for better understanding the world and how to engage in it to create positive change.
I learned how to theoretically think about current global and IR issues.

A broad survey course on international relations theories, literature, and topics. I definitely learned a lot about the various international relations theories and how they've been applied, which I thought was really important for an introduction to international relations. I learned so much that I feel will definitely be helpful in other Political Science courses. Also, the professor and TA will let you think for yourself and decide on your own best theory for approaching international relations i.e. they won't hammer one theory into you.
learned how to read poli. sci. articles better and understand multiple political theories.

I learnt a lot throughout this class. I learned to put more pressure on myself to speak up in section. I learnt how to write an engaging shorter essay and I loved developing my knowledge about the theoretical lenses and how to apply them to different scenarios.

Strengths: Professor Lyall is phenomenal 
Weaknesses: none
I found lecture to be really engaging, well thought out, and well presented every day. I would have liked to see some time for questions towards the end of lecture though.
Was not the biggest fan of the final exam format. Would rather just study for it than prepare for 3/12 prompts

It is a tough weakness to get past...there is a lot of reading, to say it was too much is wrong because a lot of time was placed into choosing important readings. i really appreciate what they exposed us to. In the end, it was tough to read, but it was well worth it and even necessary to learn.

Strengths: This course was an intellectual challenge. Being asked to apply the same 5-6 theories to a plethora of events pushed me to think critically and analytically. Also, this course is helpful in viewing events from multiple angles, which broadened my understanding of the factors contributing to these events. 

Weaknesses: There are too many readings, which made it difficult to be consistently engaged with the material. Additionally, because of the heavy reading load, it was very difficult to prepare for the midterm and final, which required an understanding of all the readings.
Lots of reading. Cant possibly do it if involved in things outside of class
I loved this course

The reading load was unreasonably high. The method suggested for forming arguments in this class was overly simplistic purposefullyI think there arent other ways to achieve parsimony than refusing to acknowledge the nuance in an explanation, and as an upper level political science major, I have been in other polisci classes that encourage that type of nuance. The course took a deeply Eurocentric perspective; even when discussing other parts of the world, it was from the perspective of how would this influence the US or Europe. Aside from the theoretical perspectives, which we reviewed in one class and were very straightforward to apply, I think one could gain a lot more from taking some history classes.
Really interesting lectures and sections but felt like the course lost a bit of steam towards the end of the semester and the focus was lost

The course is great at describing the theoretical frameworks of international relations and the development of IR all the way from Ancient Greece to our days. I do wish, however, that it was structured a bit more cohesively in the second part of the course after we finished the Cold War topics, it seems that we were just jumping around all over the place without a clear structure.

A phenomenal course. Professor Lyall is an ever-engaging lecturer, and is able to cover a mass of information during each class section. I'm glad we started with a history of the world through IR theory, so we could see how theorists have interpreted past attempts, and how the tools to interpret past events have now come into question.

I wish that we had a more systematized introduction to international theories, one that discussed scope conditions and whether the theory was a primary or secondary theory. Even though realism, liberalism, and constructivism are the main theories in present day IR, we were introduced to rationalism and cognitivism as if they competed alongside the three previously mentioned ones.
Weakness was reading amount and going over them in section.

This course provided a strong overview of international relations. Its strength definitely was in the quality of Professor Lyall's lectures. Its weakness was the fact that there was too much reading for an intro course. While it was all very interesting, it was hard to get through. It often seemed like I was sacrificing close analysis for just trying to get through the readings.

Strengths - interesting material, good lectures
Weaknesses - overly-heavy dependence upon theories/lenses, reading load very very heavy
I think there are slightly too many readings.

It would have been nice if the sections were more directly connected - lagging a week wasn't the best way to learn in that regard. Lectures were great, and Professor Lyall was always so receptive to answering questions and discussing further.

There was a lot of reading - I don't think that there should have been less, but I wish that we had engaged with the readings more in lecture or section. It would have helped build a connection between all of the course materials.
This is an international relations class but is heavily geared towards European history and conflicts.
It is a survey course so a lot is covered with no depth

The introduction of theoretical frameworks and then the illustrations of their applications made the class interesting and informative. The varied subject matter of the lectures kept the course interesting while references to the theories provided a nice, overarching theme for the course.

I feel that the lenses sometimes limited our treatment of certain issues. Further, the "feminist" lens was hardly explored at all -- Professor Lyall reduced the theory to male leaders' testosterone driving poor decisions. This course could certainly benefit from discussion of the masculinization of IR, on which even our TF seemed to agree would have been appropriate.

It was quite repetitive and despite the use of different perspectives generally somewhat uncritical. 

The content became more interesting toward the end of the course.

There was far too much reading assigned and we barely used or reviewed any of it.
The course is very interesting and I enjoyed section however, the reading load was incredibly high and dense and I struggled with it.

There are a lot of assigned readings, which do help you to engage more with the subject and to really learn the material. However, the readings were oftentimes excessive to the point where it would be almost impossible to complete them all adequately. A lot of times, the readings could have been shortened or edited to just include subject material that was pertinent to the class so that we wouldn't have to waste time reading information that would never be addressed in class or in section.

I think this course could be improved by more focussed and integrated reading schedules. Despite multiple conversations with TAs from students who found the readings excessive, the quantity of reading was not slowed. It reached an unproductive state where all, TAs and students included, knew that not all readings were being complete. If everyone was complicit in this understanding, clearly these readings were agreed to be excessive.

I would have liked a lecture series that did not reduce content to numbered explanations etc as was visible in the lecture presentations but a series that stimulated us to think and engage with the system.

I think that, after the response papers, we could move away from theoretically grounding our work in rationalist/realist etc but expand our repertoire of analysis. The emphasis on theory might have been logical for political science but felt reductive on a semester-long course.

I would have also liked readings that were more in dialogue with the lectures themselves. This would have facilitated Section much more easily. Instead, Section was focussed on reading and not lecture materials.
I think the course is slightly unorganized and tries to cover too much material.
This is a very strong course that could possibly be improved by a more structured discussion in sections.

There are a lot of readings; however I think these are useful because they provide more contextual understanding for international relations. Also, discussion sections help flesh out any complex topics.

Way too many readings. Lectures were engaging and slides were well organized, but discussion was sometimes difficult during section because it was clear that most people found it difficult to get through all of the readings. Interesting topic, and good professor, but this needed fewer readings.
There should be way less reading and more test prep/essay writing.

Strengths: I appreciated learning about the different theoretical approaches to international relations. Please keep this in the course! It was super useful for an introductory course, and I will definitely apply it to what I learn in the future.
The most interesting parts of the class were the more modern sections. I thought the laws of war lectures were the most interesting. Please keep these in!

There were a lot of readings each week. I know we should all have done everything, but it would be useful for discussion purposes to highlight some primary readings and then label some as secondary, so that during discussion at least everyone has read the primary articles.  Could be useful as well to have an office hours prior to discussion that goes through some readings that are confusing
I loved attending lecture. I found every lecture fascinating.

Yes absolutely!!! I love this class, professor Lyall is a fabulous lecturer and super engaging. I'm really in to international relations, and this class totally fueled that fire. I would recommend to anyone and everyone!
Yes, especially with Professor Lyall. His knowledge and experience is off the charts and one would benefit tremendously through being taught by him.
I would. I found lectures really enjoyable, and I know feel able to better analyze events happening around the world.

I would recommend this course if you are a political science major, or if you want a broad understanding on why states make the decisions they do. The lectures were very interesting, they went by quickly because of the content. Solid class.
Yes. Prof Lyall is an absolute academic weapon. Dude knows what he's talking about.

It's a pretty standard intro course.  Professor Lyall did a good job of organizing the huge topic into themes and issues over time, but the breadth of information prevented us from getting a deep understanding of any particular unit.

Definitely. While the reading load is quite a lot, and sometimes incredibly dense, in the end, I've learned more about the analysis of international relations than I ever thought I would within the class.
Definitely a tough intro course only take it if you are interested in IR
Yes! This material was very interesting and Lyall was a capturing lectuter
YES, professor Lyall is smart, funny, and a great lecturer. Well organized, thoughtful, and fascinating.

I would only recommend this course to students who are very interested in European history. I was under the impression that this class would cover many contemporary international events from a wide variety of countries; however, we remained in Europe for the entire first half of the class, and we didn't talk about current events until the last few weeks of class.

They put way too many readings on the syllabus, no one does them, and then sections are painfully awkward and you have to resort to crowd-sourcing readings for the exams. Only take this if you really wanna read dense boring material
Yes, its a great introduction to International Relations and a perfect fifth class. Not too much work but still very interesting.
Yes, it is a fantastic introduction to IR theory.
Absoloutely!

No. There was too much reading and the material was very boring. I dont think I learned much.
The reading load was unreasonably high. The method suggested for forming arguments in this class was overly simplistic purposefullyI think there arent other ways to achieve parsimony than refusing to acknowledge the nuance in an explanation, and as an upper level political science major, I have been in other polisci classes that encourage that type of nuance. The course took a deeply Eurocentric perspective; even when discussing other parts of the world, it was from the perspective of how would this influence the US or Europe. Aside from the theoretical perspectives, which we reviewed in one class and were very straightforward to apply, I think one could gain a lot more from taking some history classes.
Yes -- very enjoyable course, feel as though I have a relatively deep understanding of the basics of IR theory

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in an introduction to International Relations. You will come out with a good fundamental understanding of how international relations work and will be prepared to take more in-depth courses on the subject in the future.

Yes. Anyone who reads a newspaper or is at all interested in how the world operated needs to take this course if they don't already have experience with IR. It helps you understand why nations act the way that they do, and helps you understand how we ended up where we are today.
I would recommend it if you prepared for heavy reading
Yes good basis

I would definitely recommend this course for someone who is interested in a broad historical overview of international relations and the theory behind it. The current issues were some of the more interesting aspects of the course, but they were saved for the last third or so of the semester. Professor Lyall is a fantastic lecturer and it is definitely worth taking the course if you like his lecture style and think that he can make some otherwise dry subject matter interesting for you.

I would recommend this course to another student, but only if they understand that they are taking a course that is very heavily focused on theories of international relations and depends upon them for essentially all of the analysis of events. Also, they should know that while the course is very interesting, the amount of material covered (particularly the readings) is very heavy.

If the student is interested in international relations theory, I think this course is invaluable in building that foundational knowledge. Otherwise, I think it is not extremely relevant. The material covered is still very interesting, but I think the readings can be a bit too esoteric, and other classes also cover the same topics.

Do take this course if you are interested in gaining a framework for how IR works, and how modern scholars approach the field. Don't take it if you already have a lot of experience in European history or in reading a lot of NYTimes or modern events - some of the material is rather repetitive. If you do take the course, do the readings! The papers and journals you read here really are wonderful and open your eyes to so many more perspectives.

Yes, I would recommend this course. I found it particularly interesting, and a great introduction to the study of international relations. I think the nature of the workload allows students to develop their reading and critical thinking skills, and the course evaluations force students to work on their analysis of historical events.

I would recommend this course to any student looking to augment their understanding of international relations and broaden their knowledge from current affairs to include the potential theoretical explanations for state conduct. The readings and lectures are very interesting and raise a number of questions which have no straightforward answers. As a result, the course challenges you to think in different ways and arrive at innovative solutions while its historical overview coupled with pressing modern-day issues means there is likely at least one area which will prove of interest to you in the future. The class tends to focus more on issues of war which can be good for those interested in military history and theory but should be noted by any student interested in this course who is less intrigued by this subject.
It was great to gain exposure to the material, but due to the work load and high reading volume this was not an enjoyable course.
No because it is a survey course and no practical or applicable knowledge is gained

I would absolutely recommend this class. Professor Lyall's lectures are always intriguing and amazing and the class provides a great introduction into how to think about international relations and political science as a whole.

I think that if this course was redesigned I might recommend it. At the moment its a bit outdated and the readings/section do not correspond to the lecture well at all. Theres hard to find any clear takeaway for this course other than that realism is an outdated perspective and the world is heading for shit.
I would, but to somebody who was familiar and ready to handle this type of reading load.

I would recommend this course to someone who is truly interested in international relations because you certainly do become quite proficient in this subject by the end of the semester. However, beware that there is a heavy reading-load.

I would recommend this course to a student interested in history, global affair, polisci etc. It was a great course to learn about relevant topics and to get a sense of the international system. Above all other courses this semester, I feel like I learnt concrete information - facts and figures and explanations. I think I we engaged reasonably well with ideas, not always nuanced.
Yes, it's interesting and provides a good basis of understanding of historical and current international relations.

I would not recommend this course to students who might get frustrated with learning about a subject that only touches the surface of global affairs. I would recommend that class to anyone interested in social sciences.
I would recommend this course to a student as it is an excellent foundation for thinking about how international relations and foreign policy.

I totally recommend this course to anyone who is interested in learning international relations. It introduces international relations in an interesting and novel way from understanding history through political theories. It provides a solid foundation for understanding historical and contemporary politics.

Yes, for the lecture style, but understand that it is difficult to get useful feedback on essays and there are way too many readings. Engaging enough class to validate taking it, but with all of these readings it isn't a gut.
This course is very interesting but challenging. If you are really interested in IR then take it but if not then don't.

This course is WORTH IT! TAKE IT! Take it if you're mildly interested in international relations, global affairs, history, or poli sci because you will learn so much that you can apply to other disciplines or just the world today in general. This is a great introductory course, but I would recommend it to people that don't even need an introductory course because you'll learn so much that you wouldn't know otherwise. The theoretical frameworks of international relations will seem annoying at first but they are so worth it!! I truly learned so much from this class and my horizons have been broadened, even if my grade isn't perfect. A+ class you go glen coco
absolutely not
Yes, Professor Lyall is a great lecturer and the class material is interesting.  The course work is not too hard, quite a bit of reading, but not much else.
Yes, I loved learning about the material, especially the more modern history and current issues. The course was very interesting.

I would recommend it because Professor Lyall is a great lecturer, but I found it to be too theory heavy and did not focus enough on real-world applications. I still enjoyed the class, but I guess it was just not exactly what I expected.
